content: The "Greener Government Act of 1993" aims to promote sustainable economic development by incorporating environmental concerns into federal technology development programs. This includes the use of environmental technologies to enhance economic competitiveness and environmental security in the United States. The Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 is amended to include provisions for sustainable economic development, greater environmental sustainability, and the integration of environment and economic development concerns. This aims to promote long-term economic development with reduced pollution and more efficient use of energy and materials. The Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 is amended to include provisions for sustainable economic development, enhancing competitiveness of American businesses, technological innovation, and commercial applications. Amendments are made to various sections to promote sustainable economic development alongside environmental sustainability and economic growth. The Technology Act (15 U.S.C. 271) is amended to include provisions for sustainable economic development, defined as integrating environment and economic concerns for long-term development with reduced pollution and efficient energy use. NASA Amendments are also made to enhance sustainable economic development. Amendments to the NASA Act in 1958 (42 U.S.C. 2451 note) involve making technologies available to enhance sustainable economic development in the United States. The National Science Foundation Act of 1950 is amended to include fostering education and research for sustainable economic development nationally and internationally. The National Science Foundation Act of 1950 is amended to define 'sustainable economic development' as the integration of environment and economic concerns for long-term development with reduced pollution and efficient energy use. Additionally, Title 10 of the United States Code is amended to remove references to "economic growth".
